citation.article-title: Methylophaga aminisulfidivorans sp. nov., a restricted facultatively methylotrophic marine bacterium.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Methylophaga aminisulfidivorans sp. nov.

Methylophaga aminisulfidivorans (am.i.ni′sul.fi.di′vo.rans. N.L. n. aminum the amine group; N.L. n. sulfidum sulfide; L. v. voro to devour; N.L. part. adj. aminisulfidivorans amine-sulfide-devouring, amine-sulfide-utilizing).
Cells are Gram-negative rods, 0.8–1.2 μm in length and 0.2–0.4 μm in diameter.
Colonies on mineral salts/methanol agar are white to slightly cream and 1–2 mm in diameter.
Non-motile, strictly aerobic and does not require vitamin B12.
Able to grow at 20–37 °C, at pH 6.0–8.0 on MSM with 1.5–9 % (w/v) NaCl.
Optimal growth takes place at 30 °C, pH 6.8–7.0 and 3 % NaCl.
Restricted facultative methylotroph that utilizes methanol, monomethylamine, dimethylamine, trimethylamine, dimethylsulfide, DMSO, dimethylformamide and fructose.
Utilizes C1-compounds via the RuMP pathway.
Does not grow on peptone-yeast extract medium with or without NaCl.
The prevailing cellular fatty acids are C16 : 0 and C16 : 1.
The type strain, MPT (=KCTC 12909T=VKM B-2441T=JCM 14647T), was isolated from a seawater sample collected from Mokpo, South Korea.
